lcInstruction.p: Maps are used to compile, organize, and define the relationships among DITA topics. For example, a map might contain all of the concept and reference topics with information about a single product, along with all the task topics that give instructions for using that product, and a glossary of related terms. Although a single topic can be published on its own, many authors collect topics in maps to prepare them for publication.

Using maps can add flexibility and facilitate reuse in your publishing workflow. If you have content that applies to multiple products, such as common safety information, you can write that topic once and reference it in multiple maps. You can also reference other maps within a map, which allows you to group related sets of topics together (such as compiling maps for individual products into a single map for a product family). Maps can also contain metadata, which can be used to help your company distribute your content or your customers find it more easily.
At a minimum, a map must contain a root <map> element. The <map> element may contain the following elements:

li.p: The <title> element, which allows you to name the map (such as "Product X User Guide").
Any number of <topicref> elements, which allow you to link to topics that should be included in the map. A <topicref> element can contain other <topicref> elements.
Any number of <mapref> elements, which allow you to link to other maps that should be included in the main map.
Any number of <reltable> elements, which allow you to create tables that define relationships in your content.
The <topicmeta> element, which defines map-level metadata. The <topicref> elements in your map (along with most other map-level elements) can also contain a <topicmeta> element.

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of the <map> element and the map-level elements it contains. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

step.cmd: Make a copy of the file map_samples/_m_ducks_start.ditamap and open it in your editor.

note.p: If you are using a DITA-aware text editor, make sure you are in text mode, rather than author or visual mode.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>xyz</title> </map>

info.p: The first line (which begins with <?xml) is an XML declaration, which is a standard part of all XML files.
The DOCTYPE declaration on the second line identifies this file as a DITA map.
The third line is the opening tag of the <map> element, which uses the unique ID "ducks".
The <title> element on the fourth line contains the title of the map.
The fifth line uses the closing tag </map> to show where the <map> element ends.

step.cmd: Inside the <title> element, change the text of the title as shown in the following example.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> </map>

step.info: Now that you've set up the base structure for your map, you can begin adding topic references.
